div.p: 1. V:15. Round Capitol Square—alone— George left us.

Rainy morning again, and I walked alone. Lewis Williams a member of the House of Representatives from North-Carolina, introduced Mr Fullerton, heretofore a member of the 16th. Congress from Pennsylvania, and now an applicant for any Office under the Government that will give him and his family bread— Mr Dyer came and took back his papers, except his own petition— The question upon his title requires a judicial rather than an executive decision— Mr Clay was here twice— He had prepared answers to Notes from Mr Obregon on the Mexican Minister, and from Mr Rebello the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires— He postpones his departure for Philadelphia, till Sunday, that he may in the mean time sign the Treaty with Prussia. He spoke with great earnestness of the nomination to be made of a Minister to Great Britain, and urged anew the wishes and pretensions of Governor Barbour; and the nomination of a Citizen of New-York to the Office of Secretary of War. All the friends of the administration are agreed that the political effect of the appointment of Mr Webster would be very unfavourable— The secret of Governor Barbour’s anxiety to go to England, is to save himself from the wreck— Mr Rush has the same desire; and it is not inoperative upon Mr Clay’s recent propensities to resign— As the rage of the tempest increases, and the chances grow desperate, each one will take care of himself— I know not that I could do better than gratify Governor Barbour, who has rendered faithful service to the Country; and whose integrity and honour are unsullied— In my own political downfal, I am bound to involve unnecessarily none of my friends— Mr Clay thinks that the appointment of Governor Barbour, would not have a bad political effect upon the Administration— In this he is greatly mistaken— The effect will be violent and probably decisive— But why should I require men to sacrifice themselves for me? Mr Southard the Secretary of the Navy
was also twice here— He wishes to appoint a Commander of the Squadron upon the Eastern Coast of South America, to relieve Commodore James Biddle, who must now come home. He mentioned Captain Creighton; but I thought it best to consider further, before fixing upon him— He wants judgment and discretion— Coll. Taylor of Kentucky called and took leave. The bill for his relief has passed, and he says will enable him to pay a debt— Mr English came to renew his application for further employment; but I could give him no encouragement. At one O’Clock, the Arkansas Cherokee Indians came with the Agent Duval, and their interpreter James Rogers— I had a talk with them in which the Black Fox was the Speaker on their part— I told them it was my desire to do every thing for them in my power, and I particularly hoped that the Treaty prepared to be signed by the Secretary of War and them would be satisfactory to them. I referred particularly to the promises made to them by Mr Monroe, and Mr Calhoun in 1819. and assured them that we should take every proper measure for giving them substantial effect— The Black Fox after expressing his thanks to the great Spirit for the opportunity affording him and his brothers of the deputation to hold a talk with their great father, listened to all that I said, and then observed that he wished to answer it not in a hasty manner; but to have time to consider it; to which I readily agreed—and said I wished them to take all the time they would desire, and frankly to let me know all that they thought and all they wanted— George Guess is the inventor of the Cherokee Alphabet, by which I told him he had rendered a great service to his Nation, in opening to them a new fountain of knowledge— I found afterwards that he had sent me a copy of this alphabet, with a Letter intimating that it was thought the United States ought to give him a gratuity of 6000 dollars for his invention. Mr Watts, Charge d’Affaires to the Republic of Colombia, recently arrived upon a leave of absence was here, and gave me to understand that it was his wish and intention to return thither— I sent a Message to the Senate N. 29. with a Report from the Secretary of War, and documents relating to the removal of the Indian Agency from Fort Wayne. My Son George left us at 4 O’Clock this afternoon, to return home to Boston. His mother and her Sister, Mrs W. S. Smith accompany him as far as Baltimore— I gave him a tin box, containing 60 sinking Cork Oak Acorns, last received from Spain, about as many Post Oak Acorns, which I have kept over winter, and perhaps two dozen Brazilian Squash Seeds given me by E. Wyer— All these George is to plant next week at Quincy— I visited the Nursery and found along the Northern border within the fence 36 trees, coming up between the Eastern end of the Nursery, and the row of transplanted cherries— Of these trees there are Oaks, Black Walnuts and one Chesnut discernable. As yet no Shagbarks— I wrote this Evening till near Midnight.
2. V:15. Friday Round Capitol Square—Thunder Shower.

The cold and rainy weather continues, and confines my morning walks still to the circumambulation of the Capitol— The thunder shower this morning came on just as I had returned home. Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me three Resolutions of that Body—the advice and consent to the Ratification of the Treaty of Commerce with Mexico. Advice and consent to the Ratification of Treaty with Eel River Indians, with exception of the fourth Article; and a Resolution requesting information respecting a supposed reduction of impost duties by the Government of Brazil. Mr G. S. Bourne came to renew his pitiable supplications for an appointment— I told him that there was no vacancy that I knew of to which he could be appointed: he asked if he was to consider

this as a notice that he was not to expect any thing hereafter— I said it would be better if he should—particularly as I had found by experience, that he construed into promises, every the slightest expression of kindness. He thanked me for my candour. Mr Seymour a Senator from Vermont introduced a Professor Hall of Washington College Hartford, and Professor Betton of Princeton College. Mr King from the Department of State mentioned the Commission to be issued to the Justices of the Levy Court— Charles Foster, Son of James H. Foster of Boston; called and made a short visit. Mr Bell, a Senator from New-Hampshire came to take leave— He is called suddenly and most inopportunely home to his brother, who is suddenly afflicted with a severe and dangerous illness— Mr Bell repeated the advice to leave the Mission to Great-Britain open till the next Session of Congress— Governor Barbour came and mentioned a Resolution of the Senate, in their Executive capacity: calling for the confidential Inspection returns relating to the characters of the Officers of the Army— He thought it had been instigated by Coll. Wool the Inspector General, whom he thinks ambitious of having his Reports laid before the Senate— The Governor was annoyed also by base Newspaper paragraphs, and by a baser insinuation published by Polk, one of the members of the House of Representatives from Tennessee, charging him with suppressing a document relating to the case of the six Militia-Men— A Letter from Willie Blount then Governor of Tennessee, not found in the War Department—nor in the Archives of the Government of Tennessee; but of which Blount has given a certified copy from his private files; and which is so in opposition to the whole tenor of his other correspondence with the Department, at that time, that Governor Barbour firmly believes it to be a fabrication; and that although now certified by Blount, it was in fact never written by him— Governor Barbour told me, that he was going for two or three days into Virginia. Mr Kerr came to introduce his Sons and was accompanied by Mr Jenifer— Mr Bateman of the Senate and Mr Maxwell of the House of Representatives, of the Committee of enrolled Bills, brought me three Acts, which I signed. I prepared Message to the Senate N. 30. with a Report from the Secretary of State; in answer to the call, relating to the reduction of Brazilian duties— Signed an order to appoint James Newman, keeper of the Light House on Franks Island, Louisiana, in place of Gates, resigned— General Macomb called to make his acknowledgments, on my nomination of him to the Office of Major General— The House of Representatives however have passed a Resolution to abolish the Office, and there is a Bill now before them for that purpose— While we were at dinner this day I received a Note from Mr Rush informing me of the death of Thomas Tuder Tucker, the Treasurer of the United States— He has held that office about 27 years, and was 84 years of age.
3. V. Saturday. Round Capitol Square— Garden. Hail and Thunder-gust.

In the garden I found but one now plumtree up in my eastern seedling bed. The Southern bed was overrun with weeds—chiefly the Shepherd’s purse. On plucking with Ouseley some of them up he discovered several shoots just out of the earth; but yet so indistinct that we could not ascertain what they were. The wild cherries the Shagbarks and the two pot apple trees of last years plantation are growing very rapidly. Mr Bailey, member from Massachusetts called to renew the recommendation of Mr Gilliss for the appointment of Treasurer— Mr Strong of New-York introduced Mr Baggeer of that State, travelling homeward from Georgia. Mr Chase, Senator from Vermont, and Mr Temple came together— I had a presentiment that it was to ask the Treasurer’s Office for Temple, but they only recommended Satterlee Clark for some employment— They spoke of a Suttler’s place for the troops in Arkansas—for which I had already recommended Clark to the Secretary of War— Benjamin Williams brought me a new budget of recommendations of himself to be keeper of penitentiary, an Office not yet created. Mr Thomas the Senator from Illinois came to recommend Asbury Dickins for
the appointment of Treasurer. Mr Clay called to take leave—going for Philadelphia tomorrow— He wishes for the appointment of John Savage, now Chief Justice of New-York to the Office of Treasurer— Mr Rush spoke of the appointment of a Register of the Land Office and Receiver of Public Monies at Sparta Alabama which cannot be much longer delayed. Mr Rush likewise mentioned the appointment of a Minister to Great Britain, and assured me that he should cheerfully acquiesce in the assignment of it to any one other than himself— He has been very generally nominated by the friends of the present Administration, for the Vice-Presidency, and could not now be sent abroad, without disconcerting all the arrangements made and making for the election— Coll. Dwight came and introduced a Mr Woodbridge of his District— Mr Seymour, a Senator from Vermont, said he had signed a recommendation of Asbury Dickins for the appointment of Treasurer; but since then he had been informed that Mr Temple was desirous of obtaining the Office, and he should be gratified if Mr Temple could be successful. General Van Rensselaer called to take leave, intending to leave the City to-morrow. He said he might perhaps return before the close of the Session, but I think he will not. Mr Dorsey member from Maryland came to urge with great earnestness the appointment of his Son in Law, Richard B Dorsey, to the Office of Chief Clerk to the Treasurer, Samuel Brook who has long held the place being superannuated, and likely to be removed— Mr Frye called and paid me by a Check on the Bank of Washington, 200 dollars as the Guardian, and on Account of Thomas J Hellen.— I gave him a receipt for it, and also one for 300 dollars received from him 17. September last on the same account. Lewis Williams, a member of the House from North-Carolina brought me a bundle of recommendations signed by members of both Houses of Congress, and proposing Asbury Dickins for the appointment of Treasurer— While Mr Williams was here there was a thunder-gust of extreme violence, with hail, which broke much window glass, and did otherwise much damage in this neighbourhood of the City— A few panes of the glass on the Northern exposure of this house were broken— It was a perfect duplicate of the hail and thunderstorm of 9. May 1818— My wife and her Sister Smith returned this Evening from Baltimore— George proceeded thence last Evening for Philadelphia.
4. V.— Sunday— Sun rose 5.4.— T. T. Tucker’s funeral.

lg.l: “Een Sunday shines no Holiday to me.”

div.p:
Heard this morning at the Unitarian Church Dr. Aaron Bancroft, of Worcester, from Colossians 1.14 [“]In whom we have redemption through his blood, even the forgiveness of sins.” The Doctor gave us the unitarian exposition of this doctrine of atonement— He has though far advanced in years still great vivacity of manner—copious and not common place effusions of prayer— A style of writing formed under the old Schools— There is more of animation than of dignity in his deportment in the pulpit— I had scarcely reached home, from the morning service, when Mr Vaughan the British Minister came, and introduced Captain Shirreff and Captain Gates of the British Navy; who have recently arrived from England— Dr Watkins introduced Mr Binder, a German who married a daughter of Mr Sumter, heretofore Minister of the United States in Brazil— Mr John Sergeant called, and had with me two hours of conversation upon the recent appointment of his half-brother Thomas Sergeant as Postmaster at Philadelphia—an incident which has given extreme dissatisfaction to the friends of the Administration there, and in which the Postmaster
General has dealt disingenuously with John Sergeant and with me— Sergeant mentioned also the preparations for a Report, making by the Chairman of the Retrenchment Committee of which he is a member— They are bated with venom against the Administration; and all the labours of the majority of the Committee have been directed to gather fact and suspicion to implicate the heads of the Departments, and to deprive them of the means of removing suspicions and of vindicating the truth— They have been taking depositions relating to the monies paid to Daniel Pope Cook; but when Mr Clay offered to make to them a confidential communication of the service upon which he was employed they passed a resolution, declining to receive it— I told Sergeant that if the Report of the Committee should reflect upon the memory of Cook, I would send a Message to the House stating the circumstances under which he was employed— Dr Huntt, and Mr and Mrs Frye were here— At four o’clock P.M. I attended the funeral of the late Treasurer T. T. Tucker—he was buried from the house of Mr Dashiell where he had resided. Mr Ringgold the Marshal rode with me to the Eastern branch burying yard where the interment took place. Mr Hawley read the Church service, and Dr Lawrie made a short prayer— The procession was not large. Most of the Officers of the Treasury attended, and Mr Rush and Mr Southard were there. It was past six in the Evening when I got home— Mr Ringgold dined with us— Evening visit from Mr Sprague a member of the House of Representatives from Maine; who spoke of the appointment of Agents for the North-eastern boundary question, and of a Postmaster at Portland. He made an apology for having signed the recommendation in favour of W. P. Preble as one of the Agents— I told him that I had concluded to nominate him, and to make the sacrifice of my own opinions and feelings. As to the Post-Office at Portland Mr Sprague did not favour either the Candidates most extensively recommended— The weather has been this day at high Summer heat and I found it unusually oppressive.
5. V. Monday. Round Capitol Square.

The trees from nuts planted last Autumn in the Southern seedling bed of the garden, appear to be all black walnuts— No appearance yet of Oaks, Chesnuts, or Shag barks there— Only two Oaks in the Eastern seedling bed— The vegetation is most free in the Nursery— There, 82 trees shew themselves along the Northern border—3 along the western border— None as yet along the Southern or Eastern Borders— Peaches, Plums, Apricots, Apples, Pears and Cherries are scattered round the beds, mostly self planted; and with them are a number of Oaks— All have suffered, and I fear many have been destroyed, the hail storm on Saturday, which broke and lacerated piteously most of their tender leaves— This is the second enemy through which my infant plantation has had to run the gauntlet— The first was sharp frost almost throughout the Month of April— In the Yard only one Oak yet appears. Mr Lawrence and Mr Wilson, members of the House of Representatives came and recommended Mr Clark lately Treasurer of the State of Pennsylvania for the appointment of Treasurer for the United States— Mr Mallary, member of the House from Vermont, recommended Mr Temple for the same Office— Mr Rush was here twice— He spoke favourably of Dickins who was also here himself and earnest in his solicitations— Mr Rush however thought the most suitable appointment would be John Savage— Mr Van Buren, Senator from New-York, introduced a Mr Miller of that State travelling homeward from the South— Mr Allen, a member from Massachusetts, introduced a young man named Brigham— Mr Crowninshield called at the desire of Mr Dorsey to recommend his Son in Law for the Office of Chief Clerk to the Treasurer. William Lee came for the papers relating to Amos Binney’s claims which I gave him, and he read me a Letter from Seth Hunt in Alabama. All upon electioneering politics. Mr Brent came concerning the Treaty just signed with Prussia, and sent
me a copy of Mr Niederstetter’s full power— Governor Barbour called, and I gave him a Letter from the Lieutenant Governor of New York, Pitcher, with documents annexed implicating the conduct of two Officers of the Army, Hyde and Colquhoun; charged with refusing to obey an order from the Secretary of War, directing them to give all assistance in their power to arrest a man named King, under suspicion as an accomplice in the murder of William Morgan— King was a Suttler in the Army— Governor De Witt Clinton had sent two special Agents to the Territory of Arkansas, to demand the arrest, and delivery over of King— Governor Izard of Arkansas, had furnished them with an order to that effect; but by the prevarication and connivance of these Officers, King made his escape— I requested Governor Barbour, to order immediately the arrest of the two Officers, and to try them by a Court Martial— Governor Barbour read to me a testy Letter and Resolution of the Retrenchment Committee, demanding his reason for sending them some statements of expenditures in the War Department, under his Predecessor. Mr Bartley member of the House from Ohio introduced a Mr Hyle of that State, a Drover who has brought a herd of Cattle with him for Sale— Dr Watkins called and shewed me Letters to him from Messrs Clay Rush, Barbour and Southard, concerning his project of purchasing the Establishment of the National Journal; and resigning his Office of Auditor, to make the management of the paper his only occupation. He observed that none of them advised it—neither did I— Mr Southard asked if I had come to a decision respecting the appointment of staff-Officers in the Marine Corps— I had not yet found time to examine all the papers— I sent this day three Messages to the Senate. N. 30. on the Brazilian duties— N. 31 with nominations— N. 32 the Treaty with Prussia— Mrs Adams dined at Mr Frye’s
6. V. Tuesday. Garden— Ride with John on Horseback

Sowed in the Garden Lucem seed—Brazilian Squash seeds and one bean Spanish Acorns, dry apple seeds, Persimmon seeds, Prune Stones and 1. Apricot with yard floating cherry-stones. None of these except the Squash seeds do I expect to come up— I this day found in the front yard 8 of the Acorns up that I had planted the 9th. of November. Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me a Resolution of that body, confirming certain nominations. Mr Vance a member from the State of Ohio came to recommend the appointment of General Harrison as Minister to the Republic of Colombia. This person’s thirst for lucrative Office is absolutely rabid. Vice President Major-General of the Army, Minister to Colombia, for each of these places he has been this very session as hot in pursuit as a hound on the scent of a hare. He is a Bavard, of a lively and active but shallow mind, a political adventurer not without talents, but self-sufficient vain and indiscreet. He has withal a faculty of making friends, and is incessantly importuning them or their influence in his favour. The Ohio delegation are all warmly interested in his favour, and so are those of Indiana, and part of those of Kentucky— Vance pleaded for him most earnestly, and against George Robertson, who is urged vehemently by R. P. Letcher and the friendly portion of the Kentucky Delegation. I told Mr Vance that I had not yet determined to make any appointment of a Minister to Colombia, not being entirely satisfied that such an appointment is necessary. Mr Thomas the Senator from Illinois called to speak upon the subject of the Tariff Bill now before the Senate, and the fate of which is uncertain— The professed object of the Bill is the protection of domestic manufactures, but there is compounded with it, taxation peculiarly oppressive upon New-England. The Senate are so nearly divided upon the Bill that its passage will probably depend upon the votes of the Members from Massachusetts— Mr Thomas thinks it will depend entirely upon Mr Webster, and considering his vote as doubtful, came to intimate a wish to me that I would interpose to fix his indecision— Mr Marvin, a member from New-York came and introduced Captain Mullany, who said he had seen me before, and who has some unsettled claim upon the
Government. Mr Webster called, and spoke of the appointment of a Minister to Colombia, and recommended General Harrison— He had also a Letter from New-York respecting the two Officers at Cantonment Towson, charged with having disobeyed the order of the Secretary of War, and favoured the escape of the Suttler, King, from the pursuit of the Peace Officers sent by the Governor of New-York to arrest him— The Letter expressed an earnest wish that the movement of this Government for the punishment of those Officers should be prompt and vigorous— I told Mr Webster that orders had already been issued for the arrest of the Officers and their trial by a Court Martial— Mr Bouligny, a Senator from Louisiana, introduced General Flaujac of that State; now on his way to New-York to embark for France. Coll Thomas was here and amused me for an hour with his gossip— He informed me of several facts connected with the recent appointment of Postmaster at Philadelphia, strange enough, and of a very suspicious character— I took a ride of about an hour this morning on horseback, with my Son John. I have concluded to try the experiment of this mode of exercise, for the restoration of my health, which continues drooping— I was fatigued and agitated by it far more than I had expected— The heat of the day was very oppressive— My Thermometers at 81. and I found myself under such extreme lassitude through the greater part of the day that I was unable to write or read. In the Evening I attended the Oratorio, at the Unitarian Church— Mrs French was there as a singer: but the performance was on the whole dull— Home at about ten O’ Clock— My Seedling boxes of Oranges sent into the Garden.
7. V. Wednesday— Round Capitol Square. Garden— Company to dine.

I found in the Southern seedling bed in the garden 25 Trees up from the nuts and acorns which I had planted on the 31st. of October last—11 of them in a single row. Among them are two or three Oaks; a few chesnuts, and the rest I believe black walnuts— No appearance yet of any Shag barks of this year— Mr Marvin, member of the house from New-York came to speak of a claim of Merrill and Baker, upon the War Department— The question was upon a claim of indemnification for the loss by a violent tempest of certain timber, delivered by them according to an agreement at Oswego for the Lakes— The Secretary of War doubting the propriety of the allowance referred the case to me for decision— I thought the allowance to be very equitable, but that the executive had no authority to make it. Mr Marvin argued the case in behalf of the claimants, for more than an hour, but without changing my opinion— The executive can only hold the party to his contract— The dispensing power is in Congress— The contract was not among the papers and Mr Marvin was not very certain as to its purport— He admitted however that there was in it no stipulation binding the United States, to bear the loss of disastrous accidents in the progress of its execution. Mr M’lean the Postmaster General came upon a subject which is giving him and me great trouble— The recent appointment of a Postmaster at Philadelphia— My diary of 16. April shews how this was effected— Mr M’lean went to Mr John Sergeant, and told him he had concluded to remove R. Bache and asked if his brother would accept the Office— John Sergeant answered that he did not know and desired time to consult him. The Postmaster General could not allow delay— Sergeant could not put a negative upon the offer of a lucrative Office to his brother, and told him that he was well qualified for the Office, and had for some years taken no part in politics— Mr M’lean then came to me— Told me of his having already been to Mr John Sergeant, who was desirous that his brother should be appointed, and had assured him that the appointment would be acceptable to all parties. By this statement he obtained my consent to the appointment: and a Letter was written to him and despatched by a special messenger the same day—though it seems his Commission was not sent, and Mr M’lean this day said he believed the Commission was not yet sent— But the appointment, when known in Philadelphia, produced an instantaneous and most violent fermentation among the friends of the Administration, and probably a fatal shock
to the popularity of John Sergeant, who was supposed to have solicited the appointment for his brother— The conduct of the Postmaster General in this affair has been very severely censured in three successive Articles of the Democratic Press; and in the paper of Saturday last an Article of two Columns, arraigns him before the public, in terms which he has thought required him to come forth in his own defence— Mr M’lean read to me a paper which he told me he had prepared to publish in a newspaper to-morrow. The Article in the Democratic Press, charges him with neglect of his official duties in not sooner removing the late Postmaster Richard Bache, and with deep and treacherous intrigue in effecting the appointment of Thomas Sergeant— The paper which he read to me was a defence upon both the points; and with regard to the default of Bache, he justifies himself sufficiently; at least so far as to shew that in declining to remove him heretofore he had acted with my concurrence. But in repelling the charge of intrigue and treachery to affect the appointment of T Sergeant he said that Mr J. Sergeant had not solicited the office for his brother; but that he M’lean had fixed upon him of his own motion without any recommendation— I told Mr M’lean that I had not read the Article in the Democratic Press—but that among the rumours circulated among the friends of the Administration at Philadelphia, it was assented that Mr Ingham had recommended T. Sergeant; and that his Commission had been sent to G. M. Dallas, and that the deportment of those two men towards the Administration and personally towards myself made them singular Counsellors for appointments to Office under me— He acknowledged that these persons were very hostile to the Administration; and admitted with some embarrassment that some time since, he observed to Mr Ingham, that he should perhaps be under the necessity of removing the Postmaster at Philadelphia, and would wish to appoint a person fully qualified in every respect; and who belonged to and would be obnoxious to no party; and Mr Ingham said he did not know where he would find such a man unless he took Tom Sergeant. But Mr M’lean said he had not considered this as a recommendation, and had not been influenced by it to the appointment— That he had not sent Mr Sergeants Letter of Appointment to Mr Dallas but had written to Mr Dallas, both as a near relative of Bache and as a lawyer, to secure the funds in Bache’s hands, so that there might be no loss to the public— I then said that as the Commission to T. Sergeant had not been sent, I wished him to return it for the present— That a full, effective, and bona fide examination of the transactions relating to the establishment and recent transfer of the Franklin Gazette would be necessary; and particularly whether S. D. Ingham, G. M. Dallas, and T. Sergeant or either of them have or ever had any pecuniary interest direct or indirect in it— The Gazette was first established as an adversary and rival to the Democratic Press— It was established ostensibly by Richard Bache at a large expense at a time when he was personally insolvent, and a defaulter as Postmaster to the amount of many thousand Dollars— It was afterwards commonly rumoured that T. Sergeant, Ingham and Dallas were all interested in the property of the paper— The Establishment has lately been sold—the Democratic Press alledges under a pledge that the Post-Office printing should be continued to it; and Sergeant since he has been in the Office, has refused to transfer the printing from that paper— These circumstances required a full and explicit and candid exposition of facts, which Mr M’lean said he would immediately set about to obtain. He said that if the printing should be transferred he wished it might be transferred to Walshs Gazette, and not to the Democratic Press— I told him that I did not wish to enter into any scramble
of Printers for Official jobs, but wished the subject to be thoroughly cleared up, with reference to the public interest alone— I also desired Mr M’lean to omit from his publication every thing that was of a complimentary character to me— His professions and protestations both of personal respect for me, and of devotion to the Administration were warm, reiterated, and solemn; and he repelled with vehement indignation the charge of being hostile to the Administration— I told him that my confidence in him had been unqualified— That of my Satisfaction with his performance of his duties I had given evidence in more than one communication to Congress, and that I had adhered to him under frequent representations of circumstances of unpleasant character, but which I had not thought it necessary even to notice. I still confided in him, but thought he himself might in this affair have been misled, and hoped it would ultimately be satisfactorily explained— Mr Rush was here twice—with a Letter, from Mr Wirt relating to the case of Edward Thomson at Philadelphia; which has again been continued without trial, at the Circuit Court— I signed the ratification of the Treaty with the Eel River, or Thornton party of Miami Indians 11. February 1828— We had company to dine S. and Mrs Appleton, N. Appleton, Mr Binda, Dominique Bouligny, Henry W Dwight, General Flaujac, Miss Gold, and Mrs Hunt, Benjamin and J. Rush, Captain Shirreff Mrs Stewart, Mrs Tudor, C. Vaughan, Daniel Webster, Edward Wyer, and Captain Yates, Mrs Adams, John and Johnson Hellen—with myself 23 at table— My sons wife kept her chamber and Abigail S. Adams went yesterday on a visit to Judge Cranch’s— Mrs Stewart asked a private conversation with me, and I fixed tomorrow at Noon to receive her. Mr Webster spoke to me of the Tariff Bill, which he said would probably depend upon his and his colleague Silsbee’s votes and he expressed some doubt how he should— I mentioned to him the call of the Senate in their executive capacity, for a return from the Secretary of War, of all the Inspector General’s returns for the last seven years—and my doubts of the constitutionality of such a call— Those returns being in my opinion made to the President in his capacity of Commander in Chief of the Army—and the Senate not being his Constitutional Council in that capacity— He said the Call had been offered by Genl Barnard, Senator from Pennsylvania— He believed without ill intention. But he would enquire further into the matter—
8. IV 45. Thursday— Ride with John, to Georgetown.

Visited the garden, and found two new Oaks from the Battle ground Acorns coming out of the ground in the Eastern Seedling bed— Mr Wyer sent me a number of Brazilian flower seeds and five sorts of small beans— Antoine procured 8. Pots for the flower seeds, and the gardener prepared drills in the garden for the beans. I visited also the Nursery in the course of the day and found 116 Trees up in the North 28 in the west 42 in the South and 6 on the East border— They are coming up every day, and I expect there will be more than double these numbers in the course of another month— Mr Wood, a member of the House of Representatives came and spoke to me concerning the settlement of the accounts of Gelston formerly Collector of the Customs at New-York— He claims some credits which the accounting Officers of the Treasury have not yet concluded to admit, and Mr Gelston who is now eighty four years of age, and has already had one or two paralytic shocks is extremely anxious to have the accounts finally adjusted. The questions are to be submitted for my decision— Mr Reed, a member of the House from Massachusetts came and introduced a Mr Angier, and his Son from Boston— Mr Whittlesey, a member from Ohio came with a Mr Thorn also from that State— Mr Whittlesey told me that he had been informed by Mr Burch, that Mr Jefferson, while President, had published at his own expence
and caused to be distributed to each member of Congress a pamphlet, giving an account of the proceedings of the Government in the case of Burrs conspiracy, and in which he mentioned the employment of John Graham as a secret and confidential Agent— He asked me if I had a copy of that pamphlet. I had never heard of it before, and said I believed Mr Burch must have been mistaken— There was an inofficial pamphlet, said to have been compiled under Mr Jefferson’s directions, at the Department of State by Jacob Wagner, and distributed among the members Congress in 1803. and an anonymous Examination of the British doctrines relating to neutral trade, written by Mr Madison then Secretary of State and communicated in the same manner, but I have no knowledge of any such pamphlet as that mentioned by Mr Burch. Mr Brent was here just after Mr Whittlesey, and had never heard of this pamphlet. Mrs Stewart came according to appointment at Noon. Her object was to prevail upon me to write to Mr Hopkinson of Philadelphia, and urge him to induce her husband Commodore Stewart to make some adequate provision for her support— They have been these two years or more separated; after great imprudence, and not a little misconduct on both sides. On her part inexcusable extravagance and disgraceful expedients to raise money for which he has been made responsible—on his part harshness, intemperance and licentiousness— She spoke of him and his vices with great bitterness, said it was impossible she should ever live with him again; and all she desired was a yearly allowance for her support. She wished nothing unreasonable in amount—a thousand or even eight hundred dollars would content her for her brother would supply, whatever might further be necessary for her, but she would on no consideration whatever surrender to him her daughter. She shewed me a Letter from her brother, advising her to take this course and to acquiesce in any terms, which should have her daughter in her care. She was extremely urgent to obtain from me a promise that I would write to Mr Hopkinson, but I only assured her that I would reflect upon the subject, and serve her if I should find it in my power. Coll Roberdeau called to speak about Mr Elliott and the eclipses of Jupiters Satellites. Governor Barbour and Mr Rush were here, and I spoke to them of the Postmaster Generals Statement, and the recent appointment of Postmaster at Philadelphia— Governor Barbour is highly exasperated at the conduct of Mr M’lean, and earnestly advised his removal— Mr Rush had not read the Article in the Democratic Press, and was more cool. I received a Letter from Mr Clay at Philadelphia, also advising the removal of Mr M’lean— Governor Barbour spoke also of the approaching Report of the Retrenchment Committee, which as was to be foreseen will be a violent and inflammatory electioneering pamphlet— Mr Rush mentioned the receipt of several boxes of seeds and plants from Captain Mullowny the consul at Tangier; the first fruits of the Circulars sent the last Autumn to the Consuls abroad— We had some conversation respecting the most advisable distribution of them, which we thought might be confided to the Columbian Institute— Mr J. W. Taylor was here this Evening, and declared himself entirely satisfied with the nomination of John Savage, now Chief Justice of the State of New-York to be Treasurer of the United States. I told him that my own inclination, would have been to nominate him, but that a consideration of all the circumstances belonging to the case had led me to the conclusion that Mr Savage was the person whom I ought to present to the Senate— He approved the nomination fully, and said he had not desired that his name should for a moment stand in the way of the cause to which he was devoted. He also mentioned the vote in the House of Representatives this day, for the passage to the third reading of a Bill, authorising the subscription of one Million of dollars in five annual instalments to the Stock of Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— It passed by the unexpected majority of 44 votes, and was very gratifying to the Inhabitants of the District— Mrs Adams dined at Mr Frye’s.
9— IV:30. Ride on Horseback with John— Friday— Garden.

Began the day by planting and sowing the Brazilian Flower Seeds and Beans sent me by Edward Wyer— The flower-seeds which are of Green-house plants, in eight flower Pots, staked and Lettered Bignoria, Bromelia, Clitoria Florentus, Epilendrum Jasminium Muscoza, Indigofera, Myrthus and Stitzolobium— The Beans in drills also staked and Lettered. Feijao Branco. Feijao Cavalo, Feijao Mendoly, Feijao Miccelo, and Feijao Puto. After this I rode with John round the Capitol Hill, to the Potowmack Bridge and back over Tiber— Met Mr Van Buren just before we got home— I visited again the Nursery and found 123 trees up along the Northern line of the border 37. on the Western, 50 on the Southern, and 6. on the Eastern—which is an increase of 24 trees since yesterday. Nothing can be more unpromising than their first appearance, and I am for the first ten days unable to ascertain what the shoot is— Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought a Resolution of that body, confirming the recent nominations of agents for the Eastern boundary, and of Treasurer of the United States. Mr. Bouligny introduced two young Citizens of Louisiana, Mr La Vergne, and Mr Villeré junr, the latter a son of the former Governor of the State— Mr Rush and Mr Southard were here— Mr Rush again spoke of the Boxes of Seeds and Plants received from Mr Mullowny the Consul at Tangier— He said Mr Dickins proposed to make up small parcels of the wheat and barley for each member of Congress, but I thought many of them would set no value upon them, and consider it rather a trouble than a favour— We concluded to make up parcels for any who should desire them, and have such notice given to all that every one might avail himself of it, who pleased— Mr Rush had also a Bill from Dr Mease, of charges and expenses for his attendance here to superintend the printing of his Manual upon the Silk worm, and manufacture of Silk— The Bill was longer than Mr Rush had anticipated; but as the Doctor had been authorised to come, and was here two or three Months at expense, I did not think the Bill could justly be contested— Mr Rush spoke further of the appointment of a Register and Receiver at Sparta Alabama, and of a Receiver at Cahaba— The two former nominations have been sent to the Senate— The latter had been overlooked— Mr Southard spoke of the papers relating to the Staff Officers of the Marine Corps, the examination of which I have not yet been able to complete. He said that Coll. Henderson’s foolish animosities against Captain Kuhn was making more intestine trouble in the Corps— His complaint against Kuhn charges him with improper and unlawful indulgences to Major Wainwright, who having been informed of this, is highly incensed at this attack upon his character, and speaks of demanding a Court of Inquiry for his own vindication— Mr Ellis of the Senate, and Mr Maxwell of the House of Representatives, from the Committee of Enrolled Bills, brought me six Acts of Congress which I signed— Mr Brent from the Department of State was here; and asked for one of those Bills, being that for the purchase of a number of copies of the seventh Volume of the Laws of the United States Davis the publisher being here, and impatient to enjoy the benefit of the Act— Mr Brent took the Act— Major Hoops called to take leave—going to morrow, on his return to his station as Military Store keeper at Watervliet— He left with me another paper on the subject of his voluminous Memorial, which it has been impossible for me to read. This old Gentlemen, who was a Major in the War of the Revolution, is as intensely occupied with the plan of raising the Office of a Military Store keeper into importance and dignity, as if the destinies of the Nation depended on it— I sent Message to the House of Representatives N. 11. with papers called for relating to payments made to Citizens of Georgia, claimants of indemnities for old depredations by the Creek Indians— Mrs. Adams spent the day on a fishing party, and dined at Mr Frye’s— Abigail S. Adams returned from Mr Cranch’s, and my niece Mrs Clark and her daughter Susan came to stay some time with us.
10. V. Saturday. 2 Hours ride with John. Company to dine.

Mr Marks a Senator from Pennsylvania shewed me a Letter that he had received from an Editor of a Newspaper in the Western part of Pennsylvania, mentioning reports circulated industriously there, that my wife was an English woman, and others of similar character, but the more readily believed for their absurdity— Mr Marks asked me to mention so much of the facts as would enable him to deny these ridiculous tales. I told him that I was married in London— That my wife was the daughter of Joshua Johnson, a native of Maryland, then Consul of the United States at London, and brother of Thomas Johnson, a member of the Congress of 1774, first Governor of Maryland, after the Revolution, and appointed by General Washington, a Judge of the Supreme Court of the US. with all which information Mr Marks was much gratified. Mr Wailes a member of the House from Vermont, introduced a Mr Churchill of that State. Mr Thomas a Senator from Illinois spoke upon the subject of the Tariff Bill now before the Senate, and upon which they have sat yesterday and this day till near ten at Night— Thomas is now satisfied that the Bill will pass the Senate: he spoke also of the Postmaster General, and thought his removal would have an unfavourable effect upon the administration— He said there was an opinion abroad that the was unfriendly to the administration, and that he had himself mentioned this to Mr M’lean who had declared to him in the most solemn manner that it was not so— He has also made time after time the same protestations to me— But I cannot be blind to the observation that his conduct has not always been conformable to his professions and in this last appointment of a Postmaster at Philadelphia it has been strongly marked with duplicity or with weak subserviency to the bitterest and most unprincipled enemies not only of the Administration, but of myself. Mr Reed, a member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts brought me several additional papers, relating to the case of Benjamin Winslow of Brewster, Barnstable County a Smuggler in prison, whose petition to be discharged is warmly patronised by Mr Reed— I referred the Petition G. Blake U.S. District Attorney, Massachusetts, whose Report is very unfavourable to the Petitioner and with it he encloses a Letter from Winslow, and his brother, to the Captain of his vessel advising him to save the vessel from seizure by perjury, both of himself and his crew. Mr Reed still warmly pleads for his discharge; on the allegation of his inability to pay the fine and costs; and I took the papers for consideration— Mr Fry was one of the Pursers in the Navy, displaced for having failed to give new Bonds within the time required by Law. He now applies for a reappointment; and states that he did give a new Bond which was accepted though a few days later than the Law required. This Bond however is not to be found, and Fry thinks it was delivered to Mr Monroe. He brought two recent Letters from him saying that he had made a long and thorough search among his papers for the bond, but had not found it. I told Mr Fry that the question of his re-appointment could only be considered when a vacancy should occur. Satterlee Clark came to ask for his Memorial to me, of which he said he wished to take a copy. I promised him it should be looked up. He said he intended to publish a pamphlet upon this and some other particulars of Mr Calhoun’s Administration of the War Department. Mr Rush proposed the promotion of a second Lieutenant of the revenue Cutter to be first Lieutenant— Governor Barbour brought me the Treaty which he has concluded with the Arkansas Cherokee chiefs; with his report concerning it, and a map and several explanatory documents to be laid with it, before the Senate
I mentioned to Mr Daniel Brent, the wish to see Mr Abraham Bradley, the first Assistant Postmaster General; and he came— I made some enquiries of him respecting the recent appointment of a Postmaster at Philadelphia— It appears that 18 months or two years since when there was a prospect that it would be necessary to dismiss Bache, Mr M’lean had indicated an intention to appoint Norvell or T. Sergeant in his place—Norvell was the ostensible editor, and proprietor of the Franklin Gazette and Ingham an endorser upon his protested paper— Mr Bradley said that for the last 18 months he had time after time spoken to the Postmaster General of Bache’s increasing delinquencies— That in February he Bradley had written to Bache, urging to him the indispensable necessity of bringing up his arrears, to which Bache had answered that he would very shortly. That in March Bradley wrote again, to which George M. Dallas answered by a Letter to the Postmaster General himself which Bradley has not seen— Immediately upon the receipt of which Mr M’lean immediately saw Mr Ingham, then Mr John Sergeant and then me— Mr Bradley intimated that Bache’s visit here last Summer, by satisfying Mr M’lean with regard to his politics, had very much mitigated M’leans severity with regard to his delinquencies— He thinks M’lean decidedly hostile to the administration, but he has no distinct knowledge of Inghams or T. Sergeant’s pecuniary interest in the Franklin Gazette— We had a small company to dine; Messrs. La Vergne, Villeré, Martindale and Watts— My Son’s wife was unwell and not at table. Mrs Adams herself quite unwell, and obliged after dinner to leave the Company. I wrote in the Evening.
11. V. Sunday.

This morning I heard Mr Bigelow at the Unitarian Church, from Galatians 5.13. “For brethren ye have been called unto liberty.” A controversial Discourse; asserting the superior excellence of the system of Independent Churches over all others as more congenial than any other to liberty— The preacher indulged himself in some severe remarks both upon the Protestant Episcopalian Church, for putting their Liberty, and their faith into the Custody of Bishops, and upon the Presbyterians for committing theirs to Presbyteries and Synods— He contrasted these with the freedom and simplicity of the Independents, who consider each church, as a body Independent of all others: exclusively competent to its own Government; and receiving neither discipline nor creed from any human authority other than themselves— In the afternoon I heard at St. Johns Church Mr Hawley who read the Evening prayer for the 5th. Sunday after Easter, and preached from Romans 8.33. “Who shall lay any thing to the charge of Gods elect? It is God that justifieth. 34. Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died yea rather that is risen again, who is ever at the right hand of God, who also maketh intercession for us.” Mr Hawley’s text as usual contained his Sermon— In the Evening I heard Mr Bigelow again, from 1. Peter 2.21. “For even hereunto were ye called: because Christ also suffered for us, leaving us an example that ye should follow his steps.”— The doctrine inculcated was to follow the example of Christ— Between the morning and afternoon service I had a visit from Mr Edward Ingersoll of Philadelphia. He spoke of the late appointment of Postmaster at Philadelphia, and of its pernicious effect upon the friends of the Administration. But his own opinions upon this occurrence were very moderate, and he thought the excitement upon the subject in Philadelphia had much subsided— He says that Mr M’lean did write nearly two years since, that in the event of his removing Bache, he proposed to appoint Norvell, or T. Sergeant. That on the recent Sale of the Franklin Gazette Norvell did Guarantee to the paper the continuance of the Post-Office printing, and that this guarantee was an element in the price of the purchase— That Ingham is an endorser upon Norvell’s protested Notes, and in the Event of the failure of the Guarantee will be compelled to pay for Norvell’s insolvency. That Ingham is or has been interested as a proprietor of the Franklin Gazette, and furnished the Paper for it from his own manufactory— That the general opinion is that Bache’s delinquency is large, and that he has no effective bondsmen— Ingersoll had never heard that T. Sergeant was part proprietor of the Franklin Gazette, but he has been heavily ransomed as surety or endorser for Bache.
12. IV:45. Monday— Ride with John— Navy-Yard

Morning call from Mr Bailey— Mr Dickins brought and left with me some of the plants, fruits, and seeds sent by Mr Mullowny the Consul at Tangier to the Secretary of the Treasury— I set out in the Garden, 18 Cuttings of Vines 3 of Figs—and in a Seedling Pot 2. Palmetto seeds and 1. Stone of a Date— I found in the Southern seedling bed 21. Chesnuts up of a Row of 50 and 10 Oaks of a row of 50 planted the 20th. of October last, and 25 Black Walnuts of several rows planted the 31st. of October. In a seedling Pot two shoots of the Turpentine plant are coming out; and in the Nursery I discovered 8 Cork Oaks first appearing from the Spanish Acorns planted the 18th. of March last— I assume therefore two Months of the opening Spring, as the period of vegetation for the Acorn— The Cork Oak leaves of the shoot correspond exactly with the form of those in the Plate of Michaux’s Book— Mr Foy planted several rows of the white mulberry, and I planted 20 rows of Shell-barks, Pignuts, Black Walnuts and Cork-Oak Acorns, in the Nursery; westward of the row of transplanted cherries. Governor Barbour was here, and had a long conversation with me, upon the desire that he has conceived of going as Minister to Great-Britain. He said it had been suggested to him by some of his friends, and had not first occurred to himself. And he emphatically requested that his name might not for a single moment occasion the slightest embarrassment to me— I told him frankly my own feelings and difficulties, and the impressions of many of our friends.— I observed that some of the difficulties were clearing off, and there now remained in substance only two. One was the disappointment of a wish that I had constantly entertained that my administration from the beginning to the end of its term should be one body— The other was the hazard of supplying his place in the Cabinet— Considerations of a great moment seemed to require that the person to take his place should be a citizen of New-York; but the selection, between P. B. Porter Ambrose Spencer and N. Sanford, with out mentioning others was perplexing.— I should however in the course of a very few days decide. He made some enquiries respecting the mode of living, and expenses of a diplomatic establishment in London, which I answered conformably to my observation and experience. The prospect which was thus presented to him, was not flattering. I told him it was my belief that the debt hanging so heavily upon the old age of Mr Monroe, was chiefly contracted by the expensive establishment of his household in London, after his return from Spain in 1805. He said Mr Monroe still owed a large debt to the house of Baring which he was utterly unable to pay— Dr Watkins was here, and shewed me a short Article, that he had written for publication relating to one of the numberless calumnies and forgeries now swarming in the newspapers against me; alledging a promise from me to Mr Webster at the time of the late election, to bestow Offices upon federalists, in reward for his support and influence—a charge trumped up in fifty different shapes, and false in all, having no other foundation than casual conversations, in which Mr Webster, and others having intimated that some federalists apprehended I should pursue a system of proscription against the federalists, I disclaimed every such disposition.— Watkins said he wished to be perfectly sure of the accuracy of the facts stated in his papers, and I told him they were perfectly correct— In the Evening, I had visits from J. Sergeant, and from A. K. Parris, a Senator from Maine, with Mr Shepherd, Mr Tappan, and another person Citizens of that State— Sergeant read me part of a Counter-report, which he and Mr Everett, the minority of the Retrenchment Committee are
preparing to be presented with the Report of the majority, which will be of the most violent, inflammatory and unjust character— Full of gross misrepresentations, reckless blunders and foul insinuations— Mr Parris spoke of the proceedings in relation to the North-eastern Boundary, as highly satisfactory to himself, and to the People of the State of Maine— I sent Message to the Senate N. 33. with the Treaty with the Arkansas Cherokees, a Report from the Secretary of War and documents— I also made the following entry on the proceedings of a Court Martial on private Hiram Carmichael, 22. March 1828. tried for Mutiny, and sentenced to be shot to death— The Sentence of the Court is approved, and the penalty of being shot to death is remitted. The time of service of the Prisoner having expired let him be discharged, not with honour, from the army.
13. IV:45. Tuesday— Rode with John. 1 1/2 hour.

I went again round by the Willow Oak trees that I had discovered last November— The pond of water by which they were surrounded last week has nearly dried up— I take it as an indication of the soil suited to the growth of this tree, which by its nature and habits seems to be in the vegetable kingdom, what the Mule is to the Animal. It is evidently a half breed, and leads to the enquiry where and how the mixture first germinates, and whether this tree itself can be propagated from its own acorn—none of those which I planted from it last November have come up— I find this morning six of the trees near together— In November I had found only three— Two or three of the nine apple-trees which had come up in my Seedling pot 12. 2. were this morning killed by a stroke of the Sun, though it was not warm. I lost a number last Summer in the same way— They will in the course of a half an hour, as if they were plucked up from the ground— A number of the white mustard seeds which had fallen accidentally into the same Pot and germinating. In the Nursery I found 12 of the Cork Oaks from Spain coming up in apparently vigorous shoots. My success in that experiment is encouraging. May it continue! This morning before Breakfast, Mr Wilson, the member of the House from Pennsylvania, introduced a person, whose name escaped me; from his own district, a Mr and Mrs Welby from Washington County, Maryland, and a Mrs Hughes of Georgetown. Afterwards Mr Barber, member from Connecticut, came with a Mr Thomas of New-London, and Mr Ingersoll, with Judge Edwards of New-York— An insane man, who said he has for forty-two years gone by the name of Forman, but that it was not his real name, announced himself to me as a Messenger from God Almighty— He began by asking me if I believed in the Bible— I told him that before he had a right to ask me that question, he must shew me his Commission. He said if I had a Bible at hand he would do that immediately. I put into his hand the Bible which I keep habitually on my writing Table, and he opened it to the twelfth Chapter of Revelation, which I read aloud. He pointed to the fourteenth verse, and said that was his Commission. “And to the woman were given two wings of a great eagle, that she might fly into the wilderness, into her place, where she is nourished for a time, and times, and half a time, from the face of the serpent.” He said the woman was The United States of America, and the great eagle was her standard— That the two wings of that eagle were given her to fly, and the time was now come when she must fly again into the wilderness, and be nourished a time, and times—and half a time—for which purpose he had come to me— There seemed to be method in this madness; but his discourse was wandering; and I could not bring him to a point as to the object of his Mission. Mr Robbins, the Senator from Rhode-Island, came to introduce a young Man by the name of D’Wolfe, and I told Mr Forman, that I had not time to receive more of his communication at this time; but would see him if he would call again to which he readily assented and went away. Mr Sloane the member
of the House from Ohio was here, and conversed with me concerning the Postmaster General, of whose character and conduct he has strong suspicions. A Mr Hamilton called to solicit a contribution for a Mrs Ann Beck who had lost her house by fire— Edward Wyer was here talking half an hour after his manner— Mr Fendall from the Department of State, brought me the papers relating to the case of John Smith, a man who is in prison upon Executions in favour of the United States, and petitioned for a discharge— I had also short visits from Mr Howard, and Mr Key, from Baltimore— I signed an order for the discharge from prison of Alexander C. Chasley, convicted of habitual intemperance: and remaining in jail from inability to pay the costs of his prosecution— My rides on horseback have undoubtedly a favourable effect upon my health; but they are followed by overpowering lassitude, which I suffered twice this day; once about noon, which continued nearly three hours, and again after dinner— Extremely oppressive and disabling me both for writing and reading—
14. IV:45. Wednesday. Heavy Rain— Evening walk.

The weather deprived me of my morning ride. Immediately after breakfast I visited the garden, but within five minutes was called back by visitors— Mr Brent brought me a Letter and a Note from the Post-master General’s assistant Abraham Bradley, respecting the appointment of the Postmaster at Philadelphia, and some other Post Office Transactions. Mr Reed came and asked me for the papers relating to the Petition of Benjamin Winslow, which he said he thought he should pursue no further; having recently heard that there was a surety responsible for the amount of the penalty— I told Mr Reed, that Winslow in the intercepted Letter vehemently urged the Captain of his vessel to commit perjury himself and to make all his crew do the same— I said this was too gross— I could not interfere to discharge him now. He took the papers and said he would return them to the Department of State or to me— Mr Newton, a member of the House from Virginia, introduced his Son, and Mr Lively of Norfolk who he said was on the Administration Ticket of Electors. Mr Sloane of Ohio introduced a Mr Baker of that State— Mr Bigelow the young Clergyman who preached yesterday at the Unitarian Church called— He has been recently travelling in Europe, and told me he had been last Summer at Vienna. He spoke also of the Tomb of my father and Mother under the Temple now building at Quincy, which he said he had seen about three weeks since— The remains of my Parents were removed from the family vault to that their last abode, in March— Mr Bigelow approved the design, and spoke of it with strong feeling— He said the Sarcophagus was in a style of grandeur and simplicity, and bore a close resemblance to the Tomb of Scipio Africanus— Governor Barbour brought the record Book of Executions by Sentences of Court Martials and a copy of it made out for Mr Wickliffe the member from Kentucky; who procures it for precedents to justify General Jacksons Execution of the Militiamen— It appears that there are upon the Record twenty-six of these Executions ordered by him— I gave Governor Barbour the Memorial to Congress of the Anti-masonic Convention at LeRoy, addressed to Congress and which the House of Representatives by Resolution the day before yesterday, referred to me— Mr Woodcock, a member of the House from New-York came with the proceedings of a Court-Martial at West-Point upon Cadet Beers, who was sentenced to be dismissed, and which sentence I approved on the 14th of March last. A Son of John Barney’s was sentences at the same time, for the same offence (card-playing) and to the same punishment. But
Barney was restored, and Beers’s friends, complain of it as partiality, which they impute to Barney’s father’s being here in Congress— I recurred to my Record of Orders, and found it expressly stated in the remission of Barney’s Sentence that it was in consideration of his previous good conduct, and of the recommendation of the Superintendant— I read it to Mr Woodcock who expressed a wish to see the Superintendants Letter— But that was to the Secretary of War, and must be at the Department. Woodcock expressed the hope that Beers might still be restored, but I told him it was too late. B. O. Tyler came it seemed to talk of the Anti-Masonic Le-Roi convention Memorial, which gives him great concern— He is himself a Mason, and sympathises with their troubles— Coll. King the Suttler, who contrived to make his escape, was a friend and had been a boarder at Tyler’s, who thinks him entirely innocent— Tyler read me a piece which he had prepared for publication, in defence of King— There were some imprudent remarks in it, which I advised him not to publish, and he said Mr Bateman the Senator from New-Jersey had given him the same advice— Mr N. B. Blunt the Messenger who went to England in March, with the Conventions concluded by Mr Gallatin, with the British Government, and ratified on our part, and has now returned with them and the Ratifications exchanged, was here— He came from Philadelphia, in company with Mr Clay, who stopped yesterday at Baltimore, where he was received with great enthusiasm— Mr George Graham the Commissioner of the General Land-Office, gave some explanation of his answer to a second Resolution of the Senate, concerning the Accounts of T. A. Smith Receiver of Public monies at Franklin Missouri. Mr Davenport member of the House from Ohio, introduced a Mr Sheets of that State, and Mr Wright from Virginia— Mr Southard mentioned a Letter that he had received from Mr Elmer in New-Jersey, respecting the use made of the name of the late Richard Stockton, to countenance some of the electioneering Slanders against me— I visited the Nursery between 4 and 5. O’Clock, but was again immediately called back to visitors— At the dusk of the Evening, I took a half an hour’s walk— Signed an order for the discharge from prison of Joshua Grady confined at Alexandria, for petty Larceny. Signed also 21. Land-grants; and received from the General Land-Office 495.
15 IV:45. Thursday— Garden Ride with John— Sprain.

Visited the Garden, and found the Brazilian Squash seeds, sown on the 6th. and the white beans, Feijao Branco, sown on the 9th. instt. coming up— Planted 18 Tangier Orange seeds and 4 date stones in Seedling box N. 3. and 18 Tangier Orange seeds and 6. date stones in Seedling box N. 4. A plant is coming up in glass tumbler N. 2: which I do not know and one in seedling Pot N. Visited the Nursery twice— There are several hundreds of Oaks Chesnuts, and Black Walnuts above ground— The Oaks appear to be all White or Chesnut Oaks— No further appearance of Spanish Oaks; but on the South side of the Nursery, I find two of the Yard Cherry Stones, planted 11. April coming up— A man by the name of Cameron brought the model of a machine for pumping water to a great elevation. Captain Norman, came to present himself as a candidate for the appointment of Consul at Amsterdam in the event of Mr Parkers resignation, which he says may be soon expected. I had not seen Captain Norman these ten years— He has been roaming about the world in the interval, but the place of his family residence has been Baltimore. Mr Lewis Williams, member of the House from North Carolina, introduced his nephew, a Son of Coll John Williams of Tennessee— Mr Seymour a Senator from Vermont, came to speak respecting the Postmaster General, whose removal is very strenuously urged by many friends of the Administration; but Mr Seymour observed that many of our most earnest friends were strongly adverse to it— He mentioned particularly the Senators from Indiana Hendricks and Noble, and Ruggles from Ohio— They said M’lean was a Methodist preacher, and that all the Methodists in the United States felt a
deep interest for him— That he was popular as a man and as a public Officer, and they thought his removal would have a very unpropitious effect on the Cause of the Administration. Mr Webster introduced a Mr Caperton of Virginia, and Mr Erskine. Abdal-Rahman is a Moor, otherwise called Prince or Ibrahim, who had been forty years a Slave in this Country— He wrote two or three years since a Letter to the Emperor of Morocco in Arabic in consequence of which the Emperor expressed to our Consul a wish that this man might be emancipated and sent home— His owner, residing at Natchez, Mississippi, offered to emancipate him, on condition, that he should be sent home by the Government of the United States; which we accordingly determined to do. He has now come on from Natchez with his wife, and met Mr Clay at Baltimore. He came in while Mr Southard was with me, and we had some consultation how and where he should be despatched to his home, which he says is Tombuctoo— He says he has left at Natchez five Sons and eight grand-children, one of them only four days old when he came away; all in Slavery, and he wishes that they might all be emancipated, and be sent with or to him— He says he is 66 years of age, and assumes to have been the lawful Prince of his Country. Mr Vail from the Department of State brought me the Proclamations of the three Conventions with Great-Britain, the Ratifications of which were exchanged at London the second of last Month; which I signed. George Apthorp called. He is here on a visit during the vacation at Yale College where he is a student. John Forman the insane man came; and wishing to avoid the waste of much time I asked him to state at once, explicitly what the object of his message or Mission to me was— He said he had been appointed by God, to effect the gathering of the Jews— And that I could give him great assistance in accomplishing the object. I told him I would answer him decisively upon that point— I could do nothing to assist him— He said then God would operate by the means of others—for he would surely effect his purpose; of which I said I was fully convinced— He went away without making any difficulty— Lieutenant Armstrong brought me the compliments of General Scott, and a long Letter or Manifesto of Remonstrance against the appointment of Major General Macomb— It is a repetition of the argument in his controversy with General Gaines— Mr Ellis of the Senate, and Mr Maxwell of the House of Representatives from the Committee of Enrolled Bills, brought me 3. Acts which I signed—one of them being that for the Relief of the Revolutionary Officers and Soldiers. Mr Clay was here; much recruited in health and Spirits by his recent visit to Philadelphia— Dr Physick and Dr Chapman advise him to a relaxation from public cares and duties—the former to retirement from public service altogether— He spoke of the despatches received from Joseph Beech Lawrence our Charge d’Affaires at London, by Mr Blunt the Messenger, all of which he had not read; and of measures to be taken immediately upon the subject of the North-Eastern Boundary: particularly with regard to the demand of Documents from the British Government— Mr Frye was here in the Evening. He mentioned that General John Mason of Georgetown, was canvassing for the Presidency of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company— Mr Everett spent also an hour with me. The two Reports of the Majority and Minority of the Retrenchment Committee, were made this day to the House of Representatives— Everett asked my advice whether he should accept the Office of President of Harvard University, which he expects will be offered to him— I told him I thought he should follow his own inclination, but that in his place I should adhere to politics and Literature— Mr Brooks advises otherwise; but Everetts own judgment concurs with mine.
16. IV:45. Friday— Ride with John— viewed the Penitentiary.

In riding yesterday I had taken a sprain which I was apprehensive would for some days disable me from continuing this exercise—but I found myself so much relieved this morning that I mounted again my pony and rode with John to the Penitentiary— It is in a state of advancement sufficient to be completed this Season— In the garden I found no new vegetation except of weeds— In my seedling Pot N. 2 a large plant shews itself at the surface which I do not know. In glass Tumbler N. 2. Two oranges, planted 4 April, one appearing at the surface— Their taproots extending down the sides of the glass are already two inches long. In the Nursery I find 15 Cork Oaks and 5 Willow Oaks— The Cerasus Canadensis—Ash leaved maple, and Bladder Senna. In the Yard the Straggling Oaks planted 12 November, are 25— There are Hundreds of the Oaks planted both last Autumn and this Spring by Mr. Foy up— The Dutch Elms given by Mr Taliaferro are almost all, say in leaf. Antoine’s Apple-pumice, and pear seeds have put forth many trees. The cherries transplanted from the yard are flourishing; and I shall leave the Nursery here in as fine a condition as I could desire. Mr Johnston of Louisiana, introduced a Mr Magennis of that State— Mr Southard was here making enquiry concerning the appointments of officers of the Marine Corps in 1817 and 1822— General Macomb introduced judge Macomb of Florida— Mr Charles H. Appleton of Baltimore renewed an application for some appointment in the Custom House; for which he brought several earnest and respectable recommendations— Governor Barbour has a new trouble with these Arkansas Cherokee Chiefs— There was a Treaty between them and the Osages, negotiated under the sanction of the United States, and by which they stipulated in case of any cause of complaint between the two tribes, to rely for satisfaction upon the United States— Recently a Cherokee, brother to Graves one of the Chiefs now here, has been murdered by an Osage— The Cherokees demand the punishment of the murderer, or declare their determination to apply the Law of retaliation. The Osages declare they are ready to deliver up the murderer to the authority of the United States, but we have no tribunal that can try him for the murder; nor authority to deliver him over to the savage Justice of the Cherokees— I thought that the demand should be made of the Osages to deliver up the Offender to us; and then that we should ransom him from the revenge of the Cherokees, by a payment of money to Graves, requiring him and his tribe to renounce their resentment—and this course is to be taken— Mr Brent was here, and a Mr Heiskell—and Coll. Roberdeau, who is occupied with a Horizontal Dial made by Mr Elliot, to be placed on some spot near The President’s House— I proposed on the South front— Mr Amory came to take leave— Going in a day or two for home. He spoke again of his Son in Law Captain Freemans claim to be appointed Paymaster of the Marine Corps; and gave me his opinion of the construction of the Law, so that the Staff Officers of that Corps have no distinct Commission but are to be taken, or selected by the Commander— Dr Watkins was here; and Mr Watts, Chargé d’Affaires to the Republic of Colombia, who brought to shew me a number of medals struck in honour of the Libertador Bolivar. Among them was one which Mr Watts called the unfortunate—struck upon the occasion of his being proclaimed President for Life of the Republic then bearing his name; but since then subverted together with the Constitution which he had given for it— Mr Rush read to me a Letter he has received from C. J. Ingersoll in which he says the Postmaster General has no right to claim credit for saving to the public the 3000 dollars which R. Bache the late Postmaster at Philadelphia,
attempted fraudulently to draw from the Bank, after his removal from the Post-Office, and that the subalterns including the Postmaster General’s confidential Agent Simpson, did their best to let Bache consummate the fraud— I desired Mr Rush to write immediately to Mr. Ingersoll, and request a full and particular statement of the circumstances upon which he has given these intimations, and I asked him for a copy of that part of Ingersoll’s Letter relating to these transactions; which he afterwards sent me— I sent Message to Congress N. 12. recommending an Act to remit the discriminating duties upon Prussian Vessels and their cargoes, from and after the 15th. of April 1826— The Committee upon the Message relating to the Assault upon my Son in the Capitol, made this day their Report to the House of Representatives with a protest of the minority of the Committee— General W. Scott was one of my visitors this day.
17. IV:45. Saturday— Ride with John— Company to dine.

In the Garden, the four Rows of Brazilian Beans, all begin to vegetate. Many flowers are coming into blossom— The Tulip Tree and Locust, are in full bloom— In the Nursery I discern 24 of the Spanish Post-Oaks, and two new shoots from the ground— The most flourishing trees are the black Walnuts. Riding this morning with John, I found near the Willow Oaks, a Large Sweet gum, or Liquid amber tree— Mr Letcher member of the House from Kentucky, introduced Dr Ashby of that State— George Watkins brought drafts of two Notes from Mr Clay, one to Mr Gallatin, and one to Mr Lawrence at London, upon the North-eastern boundary Convention— I retained the draft to Mr Gallatin— Mr Martindale, member of the House from New-York came and took the papers of a Mr Salomon; being a memorial from himself, and a multitude of earnest recommendations of him for an appointment, in the Custom-house at New-York— I said all the subordinate Custom-House appointments were made by the Collector sometimes at the Recommendation of the Secretary of the Treasury. But Martindale said the place that Salomon had in view was that of Surveyor of the Port, in the expectation that Jonathan Thompson on the present Collector would be removed, and Peter Stagg the present Surveyor appointed in his place. Mr Martindale warmly urged this measure, which he said would be necessary to secure the faithful execution of the new Tariff Act— The Collector Thompson, he said, and every Officer of the Customs under him, with the exception of Stagg the Surveyor, was notoriously and vehemently opposed to the Tariff, and to the American policy, which it was equally notorious, was favoured by a great majority of the People of the State of New-York. The collector, and all his subordinates were also known to be hostile to the present Administration, and their influence brought to bear against it was enormous— I observed that Mr Thompson professed to be faithful to the Administration, and although I had not much reason to trust his professions, yet there was no act of his known to me which would justify me in removing him from Office— Mr Clay was here, and I suggested to him the propriety of modifying a paragraph of the draft which he had prepared of a Letter to Mr Gallatin, to which he assented— Mr Clay had much conversation with me on the subject of the Postmaster General, whom he urged me very earnestly to remove, and to appoint Jeremiah Morrow, in his place. The evidences of M’lean’s double dealing and treachery to the Cause of the Administration, have multiplied upon me till it would require the credulity of January on the Tale, to believe him honest or faithful— Yet I am convinced it would be extremely impolitic at this time to remove him. Mr Clay spoke also of the appointment of a Minister to Great-Britain and to the Republic of Colombia— His proposal is that Governor Barbour should be nominated for the Mission to England, and General Peter B Porter of New-York to be Secretary of War, in his place. He is also very solicitous that George Robertson of Kentucky, or General Harrison should be appointed Minister to Colombia— My own impression is that there is no necessity for the ap-
appointment of a Minister to Colombia, and that it would be advisable to postpone the appointment of a Minister to Great-Britain; at least until the next Session of Congress. I desired Mr Clay to notify the other members of the Administration to meet here at one O’Clock next Monday, to consider this subject— N. H. Perry is a purser in the Navy—a brother of the late Commodore Perry, and is now applying for active employment in the frigate Hudson soon to sail for the Mediterranean— Govr Barbour enquired if I had come to a decision, upon the mission to Great-Britain— I told him I had requested a Cabinet consultation, next Monday, preparatory to the determination— He expressed a disinclination to be present at this Meeting, and I assented to his being absent— He desired that the decision might be made, without regard to his wishes—and said that what I had told him of the indispensable expense of the English Mission had almost dissuaded him from the undertaking of it; but that upon conversing with Mr Rush he had concluded that with rigid economy he might get along— Mr Wilde a member from Georgia came and made some enquiries relating to the claims of Citizens of that State for indemnity from Creek Indian depredations, upon which in 1822. Governor Preston of Virginia had acted as Commissioner.
